unnormalised: Okay, so my cousin, Rajesh, found himself in a bit of a jam last year. He wanted to start a small business, a little dhaba near his village in UP. Needed around Rs. 5 lakh to get things going – equipment, initial supplies, all that. He’d heard about these Mudra loans, figured that was the way to go.
normalised: Okay, so my cousin, Rajesh, found himself in a bit of a jam last year. He wanted to start a small business, a little dhaba near his village in U-P. Needed around rupee five lakh to get things going – equipment, initial supplies, all that. He’d heard about these Mudra loans, figured that was the way to go.

unnormalised: He visited the local branch of State Bank of India. The manager, Mr. Sharma, was quite helpful, explained the different schemes under Mudra – Shishu, Kishore, Tarun. Rajesh qualified for Kishore, needing that 5 lakh figure. The interest rate seemed decent, around 11.5% p.a., but the repayment schedule… that was the kicker.
normalised: He visited the local branch of State Bank of India. The manager, Mister Sharma, was quite helpful, explained the different schemes under Mudra – Shishu, Kishore, Tarun. Rajesh qualified for Kishore, needing that five lakh figure. The interest rate seemed decent, around eleven point five percent p.a., but the repayment schedule… that was the kicker.

unnormalised: They worked out a plan for him to repay over 5 years, with EMIs starting 3 months after disbursement. At first, business was slow. The first 6 months were tough; missed a couple of EMIs. He ended up paying a late fee of Rs. 500 each time. That’s when Mr. Sharma suggested he prepay when he could, even small amounts, to reduce the principal faster.
normalised: They worked out a plan for him to repay over five years, with E-M-Is starting three months after disbursement. At first, business was slow. The first six months were tough; missed a couple of E-M-Is. He ended up paying a late fee of rupee five hundred each time. That’s when Mister Sharma suggested he prepay when he could, even small amounts, to reduce the principal faster.

unnormalised: Rajesh started working even harder, promoting his dhaba locally, getting listed on Swiggy. Slowly, things started picking up. During Diwali season, he even made enough to prepay ₹1 lakh towards the loan. This significantly reduced his EMI amount and the total interest he had to pay.

unnormalised: Now, almost a year later, his dhaba is doing well, and he’s regularly making his EMI payments. He's even considering expanding in the next couple of years, maybe taking another loan, but a smaller one this time, around 2 lakhs. He learned a valuable lesson: always read the fine print and prepay whenever possible!
